body:
This is part of #204 
I think that it's important to state clearly that the conda packaging and installation through pip is the recommended way to do it.
For installing from source, I would recommend writing a `CONTRIBUTING.md` file aside from the README, and pointing to it from the README. Otherwise the README is quickly going to become very dense and potentially deterring to non-dev users.
See e.g. https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn#setting-up-a-development-environment

issue.title: README needs more resources before 0.1.0-alpha

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

issue.body:
Our README file needs some love before alpha release
- [x] link to PyPI rather than test simple (in anticipation of release)
- [x] temporarily remove reference to paper for citing
- [x] write contributing guidelines and put a link to them in README
- [x] link to source code, PyPI, and issue tracker (like scikit-learn)


A good model is scikit-learn: https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/blob/master/README.rst

body: Installing from the source is imho slightly different from installing for development: `python setup.py develop` is helpful w.r.t. this and different from `python setup.py install`. Any thoughts? Still should go in CONTRIBUTING?

if there is a use case for installing from source while not in `develop` mode, sure, let's document it by adding it into the README. but let's not add too many different separate ways installations instructions if they are not recommended.

The interest is as follow: it permits to have a working dev version(with extra features, via the install from source) as well as a released version(pypi) ; I think it might make sens. Waiting for @eickenberg

I'm very reluctant to the idea of telling users to use the dev branch.

By definition, the dev branch is for developers, not users. If our "casual" (non-dev) users clone and compile from source without keeping the habit of pulling latest changes and recompiling every time the source tree is updated, they will end up conducting scientific experiments that are based on "nightly" versions of the code. This is a terrible toll on reproducibility and almost defeats the purpose of stable releases in the first place. And if, on the other hand, certain users keep the habit of pulling latest changes from the master branch, well, they're essentially developers now, so why shouldn't they install with `setup.py develop` rather than `setup.py install`?

Well, my understanding is that the master could include new features that will have been developed and could be available before release to new users. I had in mind to follow similar guidelines as https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch#installation

Release would of course continue to exist and available through pip.

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

body:
following our discussion on Slack, i will update this to clearly state the implications of installing from source.
ETA < 6 hours

repository.name: kymatio
